Award.AwardTitle: Integration of scheduling and control using closed loop implementation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1159244
Ierapetritou

Summary: Given the strenuous economic environment and the fierce competition that almost all industrial sectors have to face, a lot of research and development have recently focused on advanced manufacturing. The initiative that the president announced this summer to invest $500M on the Advanced Manufacturing Partnership (AMP) points in this direction. More specifically this effort targets the collaboration of industry, universities, and the federal government "to invest in emerging technologies such as information technology, biotechnology, and nanotechnology". There are already some steps towards this direction that aim in reducing the time to the market and increasing the efficiency of manufacturing processes. This proposal's objective is to develop approaches that can lead to more efficient product operations by incorporating the process dynamics into the production scheduling problem. The full coupling of process control and production scheduling can substantially increase production feasibility and optimality. However, simultaneous consideration of process control and scheduling problems is currently plagued by (a) the lack of communication between the associated research communities; (b) its computational intensity, and (c) the inherently complex nature of manufacturing processes.

Intellectual Merit: We propose an integrated approach to address the problem of scheduling considering a closed loop implementation of control in a process level. This will result in more efficient utilization of resources most importantly in the face of disturbances. However the incorporation of control within the already complex scheduling problem results in a very difficult problem and conventional solution methods turn out to be inefficient. The main outcome we are targeting is to provide the decision maker solutions that are optimal in terms of production capacity and feasible in terms of process dynamics in the face of disturbance.
To achieve this target, the following ideas will be investigated:
1. Integration of closed loop control with short term scheduling following the basic idea of Model Predictive Control (MPC) strategy.
2. Investigation of MPC integration using multi-parametric programming.
3. Investigation of efficient solution methodologies for the integrated scheduling and
control problem.

Broader Impact: The ultimate goal of this work is to optimize the production scheduling considering the details of process dynamics. Realistic case studies from chemical and pharmaceutical manufacturing will be utilized to test and verify the results of the proposed analysis tools. The impact of the proposed work goes beyond specific industrial sector since the general ideas and findings can be applied or extended to different types of production facilities. The educational component of the proposed work involves one graduate and two undergraduate students. Funding for the undergraduate students would be pursued through REU initiative. Students affiliated with program SUPER (Science for Undergraduates a Program for Excellence in Research) of Douglass College of Women will be actively involved with this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Optimal decision-making in a process industry is fundamental in order to guarantee optimality of operations, increase efficiency and reduce overall production costs. Decision-making occurs at different levels, and include process control, scheduling, production planning and supply chain decisions. While different strategies exist to assist decision-makers, the available tools do not always fully meet industry needs, and more practical and efficient alternatives are needed. Many industries, e.g., commercial consumer goods, pharmaceutical, gases, defense electronics, printed wiring assemblies, etc., face similar challenges. While the specific issues and priorities naturally vary, the relevant decision variables and problem structures are similar, and therefore general frameworks to optimize and integrate the decision-making process can have a great impact in the overall industry.

Intellectual merit: In this work, novel modeling and solution approaches to address the integration of process control and scheduling problems have been investigated. Scheduling determines the optimal production sequence, production time and resources allocation in a production plant. However, scheduling does not consider the details of the dynamic behavior of a process, and does not capture the behavior of flows, transition times, production times, and disturbances affecting quality parameters. Such variables are usually handled by a process control system, which in turn focus on meeting production targets and quality specifications, but do not consider the sequence of production which can have a severe effect on transition times and process controllability. Therefore, the integration of scheduling and control results in simultaneous optimization of scheduling decision given the process dynamic behavior and thus guarantees a better performance in terms of plant efficiency and productivity

Different integration and solution methods have been investigated, in order to address the applicability, feasibility, advantages and disadvantages of integrated scheduling and control problems. In particular, a closed-loop scheduling and Fast Model Predictive Control (MPC) methodology has been investigated, where state-of-the-art control techniques have been implemented and integrated with the scheduling problem, in order to obtain efficient scheduling models and computationally tractable solutions; a multi-parametric Model Predictive Control has been integrated with the scheduling model, an strategy that replaces online optimization by function evaluations, increasing the efficiency of the solution methodology. However, only small-scale problems were addressed by this methodology, and more computationally efficient methods were needed for higher dimensional problems. Therefore, a simulation-based optimization approach was proposed in order to integrate scheduling and control, and an industrial size problem related to the production scheduling and control of an Air Separation Unit was successfully solved. The case study demonstrated how integrated scheduling and control problems result in significant improvement in the efficiency of the operation when compared to individual decision-making processes. 

Broader Impacts: While we investigated case-studies related to the gaseous industry in this study, the benefits of integrated decision-making processes and the methodologies developed in this work can be disseminated to other industries. Scheduling problems arise in almost all industrial sections including chemical, pharmaceutical, energy, health care, etc. The mathematical techniques developed in this project have therefore a very broad application spectrum with key beneficiaries including: (a) chemical process industries; (b) natural resource and energy companies (such as providers of oil, gas, power and water); (c) multiproduct and custom manufacturing companies; and (d) developers of computational optimization tools targeting scheduling problems. And, above all, the final consumer will be the main beneficiary of any increase in productivity and efficiency that an industry can make by adopting integrated decision-making methodologies.
